block.p: Iraq Crash Kills 11, Including 6 Americans Eleven people, including six Americans from the security firm Blackwater USA, were killed when a commercial helicopter crashed near Baghdad, according to officials from the company that chartered the aircraft. Hostile fire was suspected.

Bush Defends Bolton President Bush issued a strong defense of John R. Bolton, his nominee for ambassador to the United Nations. Associates of Colin L. Powell, the former secretary of state, said, however, that he had expressed reservations about Mr. Bolton.
Delay Requested in Gaza Israel's defense minister formally called for a three-week delay in the government's plans to remove Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip and parts of the West Bank.

NATO Considers Ukraine NATO moved toward opening discussions with Ukraine about becoming a member of the alliance, while Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice met with opposition leaders who want to oust the Russian-backed government in Belarus.
Calls to Revisit Condom Issue A rising number of Catholics are urging Pope Benedict XVI to revisit his opposition to condom use in the fight against AIDS.
Pope Benedict XVI acted to ensure stability and continuity with the reign of John Paul II, reappointing the secretary of state and keeping leaders of the Roman Catholic Church's bureaucracy in place.

A Polio Outbreak in Yemen Polio has broken out in Yemen, public health officials said. The disease was on the verge of eradication in early 2004, but has since spread to several countries across Africa and Saudi Arabia.

Gay Rights Measure FailsAs Microsoft Pulls Support The Microsoft Corporation, the techno-giant known for decades as a vanguard of corporate gay rights, came under fire from gay rights groups, politicians and its own employees after it withdrew its support for a Washington state gay rights bill. The measure later failed.

House Passes Broad Energy Bill The House approved broad energy legislation that seeks to improve the reliability of the electrical grid, increase domestic energy production and save power by extending daylight saving time.

Florida Acts on Pedophiles After recent murders of two young girls, the Florida Legislature is nearing agreement on a bill requiring harsher sentencing and permanent electronic tracking of many sex offenders.

Religious Leaders Attack Frist Several Protestant leaders criticized the Senate Republican leader, Bill Frist, over his plan to appear in a telecast that says Democrats are ''against people of faith.''

Intelligence Chief Is Confirmed The Senate confirmed John D. Negroponte as the country's first director of national intelligence, with key senators urging him to assert his power quickly over the nation's 15 spy agencies.

Bush Climate Program Faulted The Bush administration's program to study climate change fails to include periodic assessments of how rising temperatures may affect people and the environment, a Congressional study found.

City's Emergency PlanWorries Fire Department Senior Fire Department officials, in a 21-page memo, said that giving the Police Department control at the scene of a suspected biological or chemical attack ''jeopardizes public safety.'' The city's emergency response plan, already signed by Mayor Bloomberg, will go before the City Council in early May.

Judge Faults Foster Home A city-run group home for foster children in Brooklyn did next to nothing to find a runaway teenager whose body lay unidentified in the city morgue for two weeks after he was electrocuted, a judge wrote this week in a ruling on the case.

Ex-Officers Deny Murders Louis J. Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa, the two retired New York detectives accused of betraying their badges to become paid Mafia killers, pleaded not guilty to committing at least eight murders for the mob. The arraignment of the two struck the opening note in what promises to be a spectacular trial.
Gene Frankel A pioneering Off Broadway director and respected acting teacher whose career extended from Broadway to the 70-seat theater on Bond Street that bears his name, he was 85.

The Lullaby of Madison Ave. Product placement and endorsement deals have long been commonplace in television shows, movies and radio programs. Now advertisers have turned their attention to the theater world.

China Aims for Auto Market A senior DaimlerChrysler executive startled an audience at the Shanghai Auto Show by disclosing that the company intended to export small cars from China to the United States. Such a venture would be only part of a broad assault on global automotive markets by Chinese companies and the Chinese divisions of multinational companies.
Big Rebound for Markets Bolstered by signs of corporate profit growth, investors made up for a sharp downturn on Wednesday.
Editorials: Crosses, crescents and stars; stand firm for educational fairness; you can be too thin, after all.
Columns: Paul Krugman; Thomas L. Friedman.
